LOL  It was funny after the fact, but when you are hauling a carry one that is small in size but heavy in weight, and you are dressed in a cute sundress with cute but flat sandals, it got to be a little much. All in all, this is a nice airport that is very clean and with lots of restaurant options. Just be ready to sprint to your next gate upon arriving!

Huge airport . I hate connecting flights . Seriously I get out in gate E and had to walk w my honey all the way to the other side of the airport to gate c . It took a good 20-30 mins to get across . By the time We got to the gate we had 10 mins till boarding . Didn't have anytime to stop to eat . Grabbed a Jamba  juice fast . Make connecting flights closer

First thing I noticed were the rocking chairs. Wish I had time to chill out in one of them, but no, had to run off to my connecting flight.
Did notice an area with a large glass ceiling, definitely gave the airport a bright and uplifting mood.
I wish I had more time to explore, seeing that its a huge airport
No communication here what so ever.  The flight changed twice already and the idiots at the gate are just as pathetic. Do your damn job.

Oh, Charlotte Douglas. I want to like you ... but like the rest of the city, the most memorable thing is how forgettable this place is.

This airport is a fairly bustling hub, and because of this it can feel expansive. In fact, I might give two stars if it weren't for the free wifi.

Nice small little airport,  some nice places to eat and decently easy to navigate when your all messed up. Thankfully for me I travel well and know my way around so it was too bad for me after I got some food in me which there are plenty of places to eat here

This airport is always very busy, but there are a lot of dining and shopping options while you wait for your plane. The facilities are usually pretty clean for how busy they are. The security isn't always the fastest here, so if you'll be going through security be sure to plan for plenty of time. They're also now allowing uber pick ups!

I've had a few connections at CLT... usually due to missing another flight, as I regularly fly Air Canada and United, but sometimes end up on US Airways. Unlike my usual stops (Chicago, Washington, Newark), I have never had an issue in Charlotte. 

It's small enough that it is simple to navigate in a short period of time. There are moving sidewalks (although they frown upon using them with a stroller) and some nice food options - both fast food and sit-down meals. Flights move in and out quickly without a huge domino effect with delays. I think I like Charlotte's airport, actually.

Since I've only been here for connections, I can't comment on the check in area or the security checkpoint. Everything I've seen thus far, I like!

Oh, and the restrooms have a bathroom attendant. This means they are quite clean (for an airport restroom, anyway) and they have mouthwash and other goodies. Traveling with a small child? There are family restrooms available as well.

Traveling through this airport was a surprisingly pleasant experience. 

Everyone was friendly.  Food was decent.  Plus they have water bottle refilling fountains, free wi fi, and rocking chairs.

I just read an article that Charlotte is now the 5th busiest airport in the US, and the 6th busiest airport in the world based on take-offs & landings. I  was floored by this article, mainly because when you're here ... it doesn't feel that busy at all!

I grew up going to DTW & CLE airports who are also ranked up there as busiest .. and which those, you can tell. Security can be brutal, and baggage claim even worse. 

If anyone can say they 'enjoy' the airport experience ... this would be the cream of the crop. Security might back-up at times, but you'll fly through in 20 minutes or less usually. There's a great selection of food & plenty of places to charge while you wait. If you're gonna be stuck in an airport with strangers, I'd rather it be here.

Lovely airport, but unorganized! They changed gates on me like 3 times on a 1 hour layover! Next time I want to up my cardio then I know where to choose a connecting flight and get my walk on!!!

Some quick deets!
- customer service 5 stars!
- dining and shopping options 4 stars!
- they have deluxe golf carts for assisting wheelchair patrons. 

Anywho... Safe travels people

Painful getting in and out of here with the construction and insane traffic.  For its volume,  airport is awfully spread out.   Seating is far less plentiful than it should be.  
Must create a lot of jobs here though. I took this picture after watching the folks all hanging out, chit chatting many many times.  I'm betting their supervisor thinks they're actually busy helping people.  Ha!  Right after i took this picture,  a 4th employee joined these 3 having nothing to do but take up walkway space.    
Not imprrssed by so many aspects of this airport.

Great fan of the amenities offered at CLT but, and this is a major concern, I travel to Wilmington (ILM) often.  The first problem is that my connecting flights are always far away from Terminal E where the flights to Wilmington land and takeoff.  How about moving those flights to B or C, especially in light of the number of travelers that seem to be traveling.  And second, CLT does an abysmal job of making sure luggage gets to Wilmington at the same time as the passengers.  In spite of the explanation that has been offered numerous times, there is no excuse for CLT's continuous failure to get the luggage to the plane and\/or the luggage to the passenger in a timely fashion.  Shame on you CLT for claiming to be an international airport with less than quality services and support for your domestic and local passengers.  Given the cost, time, and effort required of passengers, better service and support needs to be provided by Charlotte Airport.

Nope not any better this time around. Still hectic, still tons of people. If you have a connecting flight out of CLT - put your running shoes on - because it's a long way from gate to gate and usually you'll have to rush to make your next flight.

This airport is CRAP, I am sooo OVER this place. This airport is RUN by American airline which is CRAP because they INFLATE pricing by 400% I mean I can take the exact same flight out of a city further away that is more established and it cost way LESS. Besides the American Monopoly the airport itself is OLD & run down with the rudest most unprofessional workers in at least 89% of the job capacity. I will say there are 11% of good people there and as I come across them I will be sure to grab their name and update my review as there is one young man who was extremely good to my family and I when we were traveling out of the country and I asked his name and he gave it to me and I wrote it down and can't find it. I believe his name was Troy but I will definitely confirm and update.
I see so many people saying they LOVE this place and I am only assuming it is because this is their home airport and they want to have it seem GOOD, but coming from a well seasoned traveler who is from a major city (Chicago) I have to be honest about this place in comparison to the 100's of airports I've visited this one ranks in the LOW LOW percentage meaning it's one of the worst in terms of cleanliness, professionalism, flight schedules and pricing, etc..

There is an expansion in process that will take YEARS and quite frankly I'm not sure I can stick around that long to wait on this airport to catch up to the 21st century as far as technology, runways, modernlization, etc.. I travel a lot so I need an adequate airport to get in and out of. Let's not mention that you can only go through TSA Pre at Gate C.. WHY?? Every REAL airport has a TSA Pre line at each gate that's called efficiency and fully functioning. Ok stepping down off my soap box and moving on.

Overall not a great airport but does have room to be great and better with time and work.
This airport is really nice. That is all O_O

I prefer the service at this airport to Laguardia or anywhere else to be honest.  It has that sweet southern hospitality vibe.  A lot of airports have smug employees, and I understand their pain, because it is a stressful job.  Dealing with delays and angry people can take a toll on a person.  No one has given me that feeling here.  They could have a better selection of restaurants, but I go to fly not to eat anyways.  I might like it too, because going out of town is always an exciting relief.  Nice patrons and employees all around.

my reasoning of giving this airport 2 stars is only because its reallllly outdated, and im so used to SJC being so modern nice, and clean that i'm biased. there's 3 separate security check in lines which is great, but they're sure darn slow! only one person checking ID's and tickets. takes forever and a day without that 2nd person. not a whole lot of food choices as well, and their gift shops are very limited.

Probably my favorite airport in the US. It looks really nice, there's trees inside, and there are a bunch of nice stores. AND a Starbucks. Unfortunately I had to spend SuperBowl 2011 here, but there were plenty of places to watch the game and nice people to enjoy it with. If I ever have a layover choice, I would definitely choose CLT.
Nice and simple but efficiënt layout. Tons of food and drink options. The only downer are the hopelessly outdated furniture and floor carpeting in the waiting areas..

It's the place I have to go to get anywhere from Roanoke, VA it seems.  Decent enough but it seems to be starting to show the years these days.  I really have to say I just don't care for the restroom attendants.

It's been a long time since I've been to this airport. The last time I went through it I just remember spending several hours (due to weather) being delayed. I made many a lap from C Concourse, through the central area, and down Concourse A on the moving walkways. Unfortunately a lot of the shops were closed due to the late hour, but I had my music and I was in my own little bubble.

Had to fly to Charlotte for a business trip on the Monday after Thanksgiving. Jacksonville wasn't super busy when I left, but Charlotte Douglas more than made up for that. The agents - though they take their job very seriously - are all pleasant to deal with and no one was unnecessarily rude.

US Airways isn't usually on my list of options to consider because I fly west more often than north, but I'll have to keep them in mind next time. Wouldn't mind - with the right amount of time - having a layover in Charlotte.

We were on our way back from a trip to Mexico and Cuba* when we arrived here for a short layover. This airport is easy to navigate, especially when you are coming through immigration -- there are lots of signs telling you exactly where to go. 

There was a long line at immigration but it moved fairly quickly. My honey and I had all of our research license paperwork in order for the Cuba portion of our travels in case we were asked for it** but the not-even-a-hello immigration officer guy just scanned our passports, looked at us with his best stern face, and stamped us on our way. We then picked up our checked suitcases, zoomed right through customs (after handing over our customs form) and rechecked our bags. 

The part that ended up taking the longest amount of time was going back through security, thanks to long lines. I do have to say that the security personnel were working very hard to move everyone along and were really nice as well.

If we had more than 5 minutes to spare, I would have picked up some local BBQ to eat on our San Francisco bound flight. Thanks a lot, security line. 

*You won't hear much more about our trip to Mexico and Cuba since they don't have Yelp. (At least not yet.) I'll just summarize to say that almost everywhere we slept, ate, drank, visited, etc. were unquestionably five star. 

** Apparently Beyonce and Jay Z did as well. http:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/2013\/04\/09\/entertainment-us-usa-cuba-beyonce-idUSBRE93600V20130409

Decent mid-sized city airport.  Plenty of food and shops, especially in the main hub area post-security.  Each terminal is attached to the hub via moving sidewalks so it's easy and quick to get through. 

Decent food, Starbucks and even a few decent craft beers are around.

All the major airlines are here and it's a hub for American... I do believe there is an AAdmirals club, but nothing else in the line of airline clubs.

Clean and not so big airport. The atrium is the center of all the action. Restaurants and a food court are available. Rocking chairs are available (if you can snag one). Wifi is complimentary. Restrooms are clean and staffed with on-site attendants. My only complaint is that the attendants become somewhat borderline intrusive by greeting you and following you. Tip jars can be seen in each restroom.

I'm not an airport fan, but this one was pretty nice. There are good shops and restaurants everywhere and an affordable food court. The staff is friendly. My favorite part, the trees and light, it's comforting for an airport.

Though I take far fewer flights these days than I used to in my younger years, I still find Charlotte-Douglas to be one of the nicer in the country.

If you happen to find yourself transferring (and many of you there will, since most of you do not actually live in Charlotte), you will invariably be dropped at the end of one concourse and have to make it to the end of another with about 17 minutes to make your connection, what with the airline industry being what it is and all.

Should you not transfer in Charlotte, you will probably be dropped at the end of the E concourse, just so you feel like are not missing out on anything, and should you decide to transfer in the future, you are prepared for what seems like miles and miles of walking.

That said, even that experience is not bad, and security is generally not bad in Charlotte, and parking is typically a breeze, with even the decks having among the lowest per-day cost anywhere.  We even have a cell phone lot where you can wait for you loved one to let you know they have arrived, at which point you can go pick them up from the baggage claim.

I agree with "Charleston C" about the employees the tip jar in the bathrooms... it was a bit odd.  I know they do it a lot in Europe but strange to see here in the States in an airport.  

This airport is soooooo long and my gate was changed at the last minute so I walked up to the gate right as the gate attendant was about to go give her paperwork to the pilot (before the gate door was locked) and she would not lot I or the other person who was late get on the plane and we had to stay at the Doubletree til morning at our expense.   I know - that's really more the airlines fault than the airport but I would think the last minute gate change is the airport's fault.

The airport itself is nice enough; I like the rocking chairs, open atriums, and food choices.

Charlotte would be an a-okay airport if you were just flying in or out, but as a major American Airlines hub it is clearly not equipped to handle the amount of traffic through here. My layover here was extended from an hour to three to four, so naturally I went looking for some food and refreshment. Literally no seats at any of the restaurants or bars closest to my terminal. Fine! Don't take my money! I gave up on actually sitting anywhere and just got takeout at the BBQ spot in the center of the terminals. 

Did I mention how ridiculously crowded it is? Normally when you have a layover, you can quickly stand to the side and look up your next gate on your phone, or at least reorient yourself enough to find the departures screen (short people problems). Nope, the flow of traffic and the narrow halls don't allow that. I noticed wheelchair users having a hard time getting though without assistance too. 

There were not enough outlets here as indicated by the immediate poaching of my outlet spot when I got up to go to the restroom. There are around 20 for the whole end of the terminal, and people were willing to stand or sit on the ground to use them. Not ideal for a major transfer airport notorious for delays. 

A couple I waited in line with had actually missed their 2pm flight because they didn't hear the announcement. The intercom at our gate was abysmally soft, and even in line waiting to board (anxiously, since my 4:30 flight had been delayed by 4 hours) we couldn't hear what zone was boarding. Combine that with lack of enough seating for a flight at each gate, and you have a recipe for a lot of missed flights.

My home airport. It's always fun to people watch. I typically don't spend a lot downtime here and never have a connection since I fly from and back. I love the rocking chairs. They give a glimpse of southern charm.

I have only connected in CLT and have no experience as an origin or destination passengers. That being said, it's a nice, efficient airport that seems pretty easy to connect it. 

US Airways tends to schedule some pretty tight connections at CLT, so be aware of your mobility as some gates are pretty far apart. Regional flights leave\/arrive from E concourse, which can be a good 7-10 minute walk from B gates with good mobility. 

Food choices aren't great, but are acceptable. I am not sure if there is free WiFi or not.

I have to say that I travel a fair amount for work and of course personnel and Charlotte's airport is nice, it's clean, and easy to navigate for parking and just to get to your gate. They offer a pretty good variety for food and I think are trying to step it up to make it more desirable for people stuck there. 

Parking is easy they offer Long Term Parking, Daily Parking for $6 (my personal choice) and then Valet $15 a day which does come in handy if you are running behind or if for some reason you cant find a spot in a Daily lot. I'm originally from NY and compared to the cost to park up there I would leave my car in Valet for a month and it still wouldn't be as expensive!  All I'm saying is the cost for parking are reasonable here and well worth it! 

I really only travel US Airways so were always in the same area and have our routine of food stops, magazine water stops with some Jamba Juice stops before heading onto the plane. 

I find this airport to be one of the best I've been in and they are always trying to make it better.

This is a cute little up to date airport with lots of eating options. Very walkable and they have a good amount of charging stations at most of the gates. We were there for layovers during the holiday season and there was a nice Santa. 
I was tempted to sit on his lap but I didntt feel like shoving the little kids away.

Hate hate hate flying... but being from Portland, OR where my family is from I fly here and there a couple times a year. Charlotte... could suck less but there are some things they are doing ok. 

It is not really that hard to find  your way around but one of my big pet peaves is lots of displays and things like carts getting in the way of rushing to a terminal. Some of the walkways seem narrow  but that could be just me. Hate security here. I had one flight where I got delayed over night (at the airport for about 16hours) and the only thing I got was a t-shirt and some tooth hygiene things. Luckily a sweet lady who was one of those star partners(?) got me a alternative flight that got me home faster than the delayed plane would have.

Besides all that at least CLT isn't Atlanta or Newark!

I can't say much for the security here, since I connected through here, but make sure you have plenty of time between connecting flights. My flight arrived late to Charlotte and it was originally only a 45 minute connection. I got to CLT only 20 minutes before my next flight's schedule departure and the gate was on the other side of the airport.

Which gets me to my problem...

USAirways controls this airport, which isn't necessarily a good thing. If you're at one end of the airport, and you have a connecting flight, you might have to walk to the other side of the airport for your next flight, which happened to me both occasions. Fortunately, for the first trip, my flight arrived early and I took a pleasure stroll. 

Back to the first story above...

No one at the airport seemed to care or had a sense or urgency to get people off the plane on my flight. Maybe that's a USAirways issue, but the airport didn't help. I ran like heck across terminals, trying to cut time with the walkways. 

Fortunately, I made it on my flight, as I was one of the last to board. I didn't really get to see much of the airport. The restroom was nice though, and it was cool having an attendant there to greet you. The facilities seemed clean and orderly. The rocking chairs were a nice tough. Too bad I wasn't afforded enough time to sit in one.

Overall a clean airport with more stores and restaurants than normal. This really helped our 5.5 hour layover go by faster.

FREE wifi - but watch out, it times out every 45 minutes.

What makes this place unique is their numerous rocking chairs available, bathroom attendants, but unfortunately no seat covers.

Busy and confusing. It's a nice and large open space filled with many escalators and walking escalators. The people are friendly and do try their best to help. Every terminal\/section has a special desk where people who have missed their flights can go to rebook and\/or get on standby flights. Unfortunately, the customer service desks cannot handle situations where there is a large number of people who need help. The lines can get absolutely ridiculous!! 

Overall, a relatively comfortable area (for an airport) with plenty of food options.

You can tell that somewhere, somebody is trying to provide a positive service culture here. It is however lost on the mostly clean restrooms, the nonsensical adventure to baggage and the longest wait for baggage I've ever had. That's saying something considering I travel 80% of the year.

How could I not review my favorite airport? CLT it the best hub in the US. its a walking airport that has lots of moving walkways. I'm as swift as an NFL Running Back in this place but throw in those walkways and I'm Hall of Fame material. CLT has many cool places to eat and drink and the price points are reasonable. The waiting areas are always clean and there's no tattered seats. You can always find an outlet to charge your electronics and the bathrooms are always clean. One note is (and this is just a personal observation) I'm not a big fan of the bathroom attendant. I'm not looking for pleasantries when I'm having a whiz. Really! who eats mints from the toilet? GROSS! The true fact is these guys keep the lavatories clean. I am just not chatty when I'm peeing.
On the occasions when Charlotte is my destination the baggage claim is super fast and efficient. Security is never a hassle and the check in at the ticket counters are friendly and always super nice.
I normally fly 1st class so we get an elevated level at the counters anyway. You should try it, nothing beats getting hammered on a 6am flight to Tulsa.
CLT is in my opinion the best big hub airport in the country.

A slightly chaotic but convenient airport.  Has many bars and eateries for the hungry traveler.  You'll also see flight clubs for the elite traveler.   This is a mega hub for the airline so you'll have many shopping options during your visit.

I've flown several overnight flights on US Airways from San Diego to Norfolk and always stop here.  The first thing I see getting of the plane is Bojangles, love it!  Good airport, never delayed.....knocking on wood.

This is by far one of the warmest and most crowded airports I've been to.

I'm not sure how big this airport is, but after taking a stroll throughout the whole facility, I saw that every terminal was bustling with people. Seats were filled up and many people were standing up while waiting for their flight.

Restrooms are fairly clean -- I like how there are attendants there ensuring that the sinks were dry and that there are paper towels in every dispenser. Hey, they even have a basket of candy there, too. I'm surprised some US airports have that -- I usually see attendants in overseas airports.

Most of the airport staff members are friendly. Shop owners were also friendly to talk to while shopping for a few things. The selection of restaurants, however, isn't too great. Then again, if your layover isn't too long, that shouldn't be too big of an issue.

There's free WiFi but it takes forever for me to connect, whether on my iPhone or my Mac. Also, this airport needs more charging stations; there aren't enough to go around for the thousands of people who go through the terminals.

And YES, as Skye A. mentions, PLEASE turn the damn AC on in EVERY terminal! It sucks when you get in an argument with the Sbarro cashier -- it sucks even more knowing that the heat is adding to your frustration!

I like this airport.  Check-in hasn't ever been bad for me.  Security\/TSA has been as good as one could expect.  If you have time to spare, the rocking chairs rock!  Plus, the food choices are top notch!

They are work on the baggage claim area, it seems...which this area is pretty much a dungeon at the moment.

OH!  What's with the terrifying Queen Charlotte statue in front of the airport?!?!?!  I'm a grown man and that thing almost had me running in the opposite direction, screaming, with arms in the air!!!

Free wifi!

I don't really fly that much and have only been to a handful of airports. Being that I live near Charlotte, I suppose I am biased towards CLT. There have been a few mishaps here. On one occasion, my flight to Chicago was delayed 4 times then cancelled. But, I suppose to the seasoned flyer that is normal. I also recently flew to BWI from here and have no complaints. The options for food are good here as well, especially Salsarita's. If I had a layover here, even though this is my home airport, I would be happy.

They have the best USO i have ever been to. 

The rocking chairs are great to sit and people watch, and this place is always clean!

I have travelled through this airport 3 times now. The first time was 3 years ago prior to being a Yelper and, I had experienced several delays, and was late to my destination. However last week, I visited NC and went through there twice to make connecting flights. 

First I must say the amenities and the sheer number of options of restaurants and shops is impressive for a small airport. They have fried chicken places, vegetarian restaurants, a bookstore, nail salon, almost anything you can think of needing here. It's well kept and clean, and the bathrooms were nice. They also have free wifi and rocking chairs which are a pretty neat feature of the airport. 

However, the biggest issue I had with this airport is that getting to the other side of the airport was a slow and arduous process. It's kind of small, and during rush hours and in consideration of making a connecting flight, it can become very cumbersome to travel through. The reason why this is is because it is much smaller compared to others and its aisles aren't very wide. Yet at the same time, they have these large transports going around ferrying people to their destinations. Not a problem, except they stop traffic behind them sometimes and make it difficult to get past them because of the rush. I was also upset that the woman driving an empty one was moving so slow and stopping to chat with people when in fact I was trying to get past her and couldn't because the traffic going in the other direction was moving fast. I think they need smaller transport vehicles here, because bigger is certainly not better as far as this airport goes. 

As for the staff here, they are ok. A bit rushed at times, and as I said earlier, there was a woman who held me up and almost made me late for my connecting flight which was at the opposite end from where I landed. 

Overall, this isn't a bad airport, I just had some bad experiences here. Just be sure to give yourself much more than a 45 minute to an hour layover time.

This is a big, nice, and modern airport. Everything is easy to find, but since it's a big airport, you might have a hard time catching a connecting flight if your first flight is delayed. Man, I hate having to run through an airport terminal! There's plenty of good food options here if you're ever stuck here on a long layover.

Medium sized airport with plenty of opportunities to separate you from your cash once you've cleared security.
Parking is a breeze: watch the signage, follow the direction, park, take a picture of your car and your route to the vestibule. Then it's just a short bus ride to the terminal.
Security seems no more bothersome, intrusive, or inept than anywhere else: have all your documents ready, put your stuff if the bucket, go through the scan-o-matic, collect your belongings, get on with life... It is so easy when everybody pays attention and follows directions.
Really, the main things keeping this place from a five-star rating are the attitudes and behaviour of the people using the facility and the absence of a 'time-out' room.

This airport is massive. A hub for US Airways so I've had to trek through here a few times. During one visit, I was traveling while recovering from a broken leg. Our plane was a bit delayed so my connection would have been too quick for me to hobble through the airport with my boot. I asked the flight attendant if she could call ahead to have one of the airport assist trams waiting for me and she returned to let me know that it wouldn't be a problem and that one would be waiting for me. Sure enough when I landed there was ....NO ASSIST TRAM. Someone at the counter there called ahead for someone to "rush' to our gate and drive me over the three terminals. Luckily I made it just in time, but the staff was definitely not quite up to par. Besides that, the other times I've been there have been fine. A good selection of restaurants, free wi-fi and other regular airport amenities etc. Just be prepared to get your workout if you have to walk to another terminal.

I love this airport.  Small enough to get in, around, and out of the airport and large enough to get decent direct flights to most cities.  Parking is cheap but could use more better restaurant options.
A great  airport to me has a good variety of food, multilple bars, plenty of places to sit\/sprawl out, and HELLA power sockets. CLT has all of the above.
Quickest airport I've been through! The precheck facility allows you to roll through with a jacket and shoes! Also no headache with taking your laptop out!
The terminals are close enough.. No need to worry about skytrain transfers - phew! Clean toilets with mints to freshen up
Been in three airports on our trip to North Carolina. I know it's summer. What happen to the air conditioning. They've lied if its about being GREEN. It's about the other green!!!

Worst airport I've ever been through.  At first, we were detained for 50 minutes after landing on the tarmac, they wouldn't allow the airline to let us off the plane because there were "too many people in the customs hall".  When we were finally allowed to deboard, the line through immigration (on a Tuesday night, no less, hardly peak time for international arrivals) it was an absolute clusterf***.  The employees showed zero sense of urgency and when I finally made it through customs and went back through security, the TSA employee decided it would be a good idea to have a five-minute friendly chat with the people in front of me before they put their stuff on the conveyor belt.  Airport security is not the place for socializing! Some of us would actually like to get home to our families.  Needless to say, I missed my flight by 3 minutes despite having a 2 hour connection window.  Ridiculous. Never connecting through Charlotte again.

I hate this airport almost as much as I hate Charlotte. 

Terrible taxing, always delayed, horrible layout, and miserable service. If possible, I will aim for RDU any day. 

Man, I hate this airport.
I am not a fan of the ladies in the restroom talking to me and trying to assist me while I have a private bathroom experience.  Seriously, it's a bit much.
This airport is kind of crappy and old in general. I'm glad I had to run through between flights. Wouldn't recommend flying through here if you can avoid it... Not if you are on USAir you can't :)
Rocking chairs, BBQ and free wireless. If it were not for the fact I often get layovers here longer than it would take me to drive home, I would give it a 5.

Nice big airport. Just hate that my flight always lands at the B gate and I have 15 minutes to get to the E Gate in this monstrosity. If you have a 3 hour layover though, there is a ton of stuff to do here. Probably one of the cleanest airports I have been to.

Pretty efficient as far as airports go. Usually an hour preflight is good depending on where you're going. I generally fly us airways and have never encountered a problem with anything. Smooth lines for security and I recommend going through the d\/e checkpoint as it almost always seems to be less congested and quicker than it's counterparts!  Happy flying :)

CLT reminds me of what CVG used to be- huge, hub of a major carrier, lots of concourses, plenty of dining options and most importantly delayed flights. CVG was notorious for flights not leaving on time and since Delta moved it's hub to Detroit it is like a ghost town. 

Anyway I digress- As others have stated there is limited seating in the gate area and it seems like every seat is taken and the number of electric outlets are lacking.

I spent altogether too much time here over the past two days in layover land, but it wasn't the worst airport experience ever... rocking chairs, plenty of 'nail clipper, magazines & earbuds' stores, a wine bistro with a live pianist, and of course, Carolina accents all-around yaaaaa'll.

One major complaint - you need more outlet stations for plugging sh*t in, Charlotte! I shouldn't need to walk past 20 gates to find a station that is nearly full and unpleasantly crowded. You're a layover airport and you need more of these. Please.

I did love the 'ritas and beans at Taquileria, and that did kill some time. Some deliciously tequila-ey time!

Sidenote - totally leaned on my Kindle and smashed it here. :( Don't lean on your Kindle.

Charlotte Douglas has really evolved over the last few years.  They have made some great improvements both in services and restaurant options.  

It gives off a very open feeling in the main part of the airport.  There are a lot of Windows that bring in natural light.  To the traveler that's important as you don't feel that you are cooped up.  

The only thing that I don't like about the airport is the bathroom attendants.  I say this for a number of reasons. 

1.   It's just creepy. 
2.  There isn't a ton of room in the bathrooms with all of the traffic and these guys just get In he way.  
3.  ITS CREEPY!!!!!

Landed around 7am on a Monday and was surprised to find the airport so poppin'! Lots of people... I could only imagine how busy it would be on a Friday. I liked that there were many dining options and shops & dining were already opened. It's a large airport but in an orderly fashion. Good place for a layover!

I fly a lot to and from the west coast and I love this airport. Definitely in my top 10. I would suggest making any connections at this airport if you can. 

Not inparticular that I love about it, but I just like it.

Quand est-ce que les humains vont comprendre que du tapis, c'est dégueulasse? Anyway. Il y a 5 minutes, je ne savais même pas dans quel État j'étais. Ça arrive, ne pas savoir.

L'aéroport n'est pas trop grand. Ça l'est juste assez pour explorer pendant une petite heure. C'est très joli et moderne, tout est très clairement indiqué, il y a plusieurs commerces intéressants (et 8 Starbucks je pense (sans farce)). 

Par contre, les couloirs sont très peu spacieux, on se marche sur le pieds. Les mautadits karts pour personnes à mobilité réduite qui passent aux 2 minutes (sans exagération) sont immenses et font un bruit simplement insupportable, un bip bip bip strident à souhait.

Tous les bancs ont des accoudoirs, alors pour le roupillon, il faut se contenter du tapis. 

Une étoile pour le style, une autre pour les commerces et une autre pour souligner le bon service offert aux personnes vivant avec des limitations. Ça doit être pas mal, au nombre de karts qui passent.

Et oh, free wifi. ;)

My first plane ride through Charlotte  North Carolina. You know I know I have been through air here but I think I also rented a car here. Service here was okay. Car rental was confusing because it was a different shuttle ride away or something.
This place is pretty nice.  Looks relatively new and is pretty clean.  Good spots to eat and shop.  Terminal is easy to navigate.  I would not be upset if I had a layover here in the future.

Slowest freaking TSA ever. Make sure to arrive early. I had everything ready to go on my tests as well as the people in front of me and if felt like TSA was going to set up for a BBQ. Too much talking and less getting people through the lines.

As airports go this one is among my favorites.  Lots of shops, eateries, and an attempt or two to sell local craft beers in "Carolina Beer Co," (terminal D) and "A Taste of Carolina" in Terminal B.  but see my Carolina Beer review.  AVOID ...seriously ...that crappy tequila taqueria place that is about the most boring Mex food I've ever had.  Taco Bell destroys it...nuff said.

And yes...the rocking chairs and free wifi are charming
Easy to navigate. Plenty of food options. Careful about the distance between terminals though..

We had no trouble flying in here and getting to the rental car area.  Looks like it's new\/under construction.  Easy to walk in.  They do not have enough cars though.  We lucked out and got the last one and were encouraged to return about the same time of day when we came back(~6:30am). 

Coming back we easily found the rental car area to drop off, and again, it's a very short walk in to the terminal.  

As we looked for the security area guards were giving out the names of the shorter lines.  We did opt to walk all the way down to a shorter line and it was short.  However, then we had to walk all the way back toward the terminal we needed.  We found the main terminal area to have plenty of food options for breakfast, and even more down the terminal hall!  Lots of places to charge devices while waiting.  

Biggest negative was the wait to take off.  I flew out of Charlotte many times decades ago and it was the same problem then.  Not sure what the issue is, but not once did they update our status on the runway.  Why is there always a line to fly out of here?  

Overall a great airport experience ....but know you may wait on the runway

The terminal is freezing. Oh and thanks for the option to buy a paper thin hoodie for $20 or a paper thin blanket for $15.  The warmest place I have found in the airport is the restroom, Even the workers inside the terminal have their winter coats on.

What better way to be welcomed back into the Carolinas then by an obvious display of BBQ and Krispy Kreme.  The view out of the gate windows gives you a great skyline view of the city.  I had a little bit of time to spend at this airport in between flights and utilized the charging stations to reboot all of my tech.  Plenty of food and drink selections and a relaxed atmosphere on this visit.  I wasn't sure if I should tip the restroom attendant, and he didn't seem to appreciate my attempt at a high five as I was walking from the urinal to the sink (humor).  I joke though.  This is a very nice airport and I'm happy to have a layover here any time that I'm flying.
Thanks to AA I was stuck here all night with nothing to drink and sleeping in a chair.  Please have machines available after hours when customers are forced to sleep in the airport.

Not a fan of this airport.  I feel like the terminals are more narrow, there is never anything close to enough seats even for small-ish flights and TSA is worse here than I ever experienced.  One female TSA lady yelled at the woman in front of me to go right near the scanner even though she was were people typically wait just at the edge of the mat.  The person in the scanner actually had to come back out, so now the person in front of me was in the way.  The way the TSA lady spoke to her was more like we were in prison.  I should have gotten the TSA persons name and reported her...but then I would probably end up being treated worse.  When it was my turn I got frisked like I was wearing and AK over my shoulder.  I want to be safe, I want everyone to be safe, but I had almost no clothes on and they had already patted me down.  I think if I was naked they still would have been searching.  I am going to avoid Charlotte at all costs...not just because of TSA either.  They have the most expensive rental cars for a major airport that I can recall.  I never rent at the airport there, always in the city...which means 2 taxis or bus rides just to get the car.  I will agree with others, there is a better than average food selection...but that's it.  I don't care how many rocking chairs they have the TSA agents crawling up my butt for nothing can stick em where the sun don't shine.  Power hungry f-s some of them.  Giving +1 star for food, mouthwash in the bathrooms and just being a good place to fly into for Asheville\/Myrtle Beach\/Charleston.

Oh yeah, before I forget, always windy which makes for hairy take off's and landings...This has happened every time I fly into CLT.

About US AIRWAYS LOUNGE in terminal C.

Crowded, and not exclusive. There must be some kind of state law regulating this place, because you can't serve yourself alcohol. There is a crowded bar with loud people making it unpleasant to sit down and relax before my long flight. And I got IDed, which makes no sense.
Chairs and couches are not very comfortable. But I'll give it 3 stars because the staff around the room are very nice, and always smile at me when they go by.

This airport is interesting to say the least. I've flown into here 100's of times and each time is an experience. 
Restrooms:  I try to avoid the restroom at all cost, primarily because the attendants hustle you for tips. All public ladies restrooms have mouthwash and mints along with an attendant who gives you a paper towel and reminds you where the tip jar is. 
Customer Service:  Disappointing. I fly with my dog all of the time and I pay for his ticket. During a recent trip, one of the American Airlines gate agents swore up and down that I did not have a valid ticket for the dog to fly. It got to the point where I had to pull up the statement on the AA website to prove to her that I paid. I was humiliated as the woman made such a scene. I was flying first. By the time she was done attacking me, the entire plane was already loaded and all overhead compartments were filled (even the first class cabin) and the flight attendants had to reshuffle to accommodate my bag. 

Terminal Service:  Somewhere in terminal E around gate 12 there is a woman who works at one of the open shops who CONSTANTLY sings. She sings and sings and sings. If it's a Monday, she sings a song about Monday, if it's raining she sings about the rain. It's nice and friendly, I get it however if your sitting in the gate area, it's becomes uncomfortable and annoying. I bought a water and a magazine and she sang about the entire process as I was checking out to the tune of jingle bells "coming to the check-out lane, looks like you found sumthanggg"..... It was torture. 
Shopping\/Amenities :  Decent. I give the airport 2 stars due to the nail salon, they do excellent work in a short amount of time and also give great chair massages. They have shops like Brooks Brothers, Johnston Murphy, Erwin Pearl and the like. 

Restaurants:  Disappointing. I usually only go to the Mexican restaurant for the black bean soup. Other than that, it's just a bunch of chains. 

Like I said, this airport is always an experience. Unfortunately if I want to go home, I have to fly through here so it's unavoidable.

Huge airport that is a bit hard to navigate especially when running from terminal to terminal however they had a lot of food options and all were good.  They also had a lot of little shops that believe it or not were not incredible expensive.

Not too bad. There are a few decent places to eat and there's free wi-fi, which is a huge plus. The signage is really easy to find, so getting from one place to another in the airport is pretty straightforward. The most important thing is the TSA security point is efficient. You don't have to wait in line forever like at some airports.

If you're stuck on a layover here, stay in the airport. The surrounding area is pretty crappy.
It's ok... As far as airports go!  I quite enjoy sitting back and watching people sprint barefoot through the airport to get to their connection!!!!

I come here a lot. I used to fly in US Airways and this was one of their hubs. Now that they've merged with American, it still serves the same. The airport is kinda big so wear proper shoes. Also, this airport is notorious for not having gate agents ready when you land and your flight already arriving late so be prepared for the run of your life (your two flights are never anywhere near each other). I'm pretty sure I unknowingly have assault charges because of this airport. I have had to run from E50 to B15 in business shoes toting a business roller and using every moving runway more times than I can count. My FloJo moments involved me shoving the elderly, children, workers, etc as I only had 10 minutes to make my next flight's boarding. That's what this airport is about. I owe my weight loss to this airport because I'm almost certain that my run is about 1\/2 mile. 

My only request is mile markers and I'm so serious. I'd like someone to tell me how far I've run when I've busted a move from this gate to that gate. I'm counting calories and I need to know! 

There are decent food options here, but my fav place to visit (when I have a decent layover between flights) is the Terminal Gateway Spa near the D\/E gate terminal. I'd much have a massage than eat. Oh and the addiction of the MAC cosmetics store.... yass!!! 

I'm trying to think of how this place could be better. They have sushi, froyo, fried chicken, a spa, cosmetics store... maybe a bulk candy store?! If they get a bulk candy store and a Rita's Ice, I'd move in. Like seriously, forget my connecting flight... I'm staying here FOR-EVER!!

My experience at Charlotte-Douglas International Airport wasn't the best. We landed and taxied. We had to wait about 20 minutes for a gate to open up for us to park. Then once we got to the gate we had to wait about another 20 minutes for a person to drive the gangway up to the airplane.  The pilot explained all this and that no one was answering the radio that they were coming over. This was all at 11:30pm so the airport wasn't busy at all. I know it's a busy airport but I expected a little better service than 40 minutes to get off the plane.
If you connect in Charlotte expect constant delays!!!!!   Every time I connect through to Dulles I experience planes with mechanical delays

I am US Airways miles holder so most of my trips route through Charlotte. It by far one of my favorite airports. It is easy to navigate  and has plenty of choices for food and shopping if you have a long layover.

Crazy disorganized airport. Although we were there only for connecting flights, we sat on tarmac for 30 minutes after landing both coming AND going. Pilot joked while we sat there, "I think they know we're here???" Get it together Charlotte.

I was actually quite impressed by this airport.  Two things stood out for me:  their free wi-fi, which was surprisingly fast for being free; and the fact that they have restrooms (with personal attendants, which is a little weird at first) like every twenty feet.  Very nice place if you have to have a longish layover, or have a small bladder.  One of these days, I want to sit in one of those white rocking chairs they have in the main concourse, right across from the NASCAR store.
International availability! Gotta love it.

Coming from Norfolk I just assumed that all airports were navigatable in less than 10 minutes.  Wrong! I was thoroughly mistaken.  On my buisness trip to Columbia I flew into gate A7 from and my connecting flight was at gate E35.  I looked so foolish asking "So where is the shortcut so I don't have to walk all the way around the airport." Lol 

This airport is like a travel desitnation within itself with a mulitude of starbucks, convenience stores, fast food, and sit down resturants.  It made my my walk all the way around this airport a sightseeing adventure within itself; Moreover, this isn't the worst airport to have a plane delay or layover because there's so much to do.

I've only arrived\/departed CLT once, so I'm no expert, but it seems small for a city the size of Charlotte (seems even smaller than RDU). 

I liked that there's only one place to drop people off and it didn't even seem to crowded. 

I had to get the full pat down (could have used a Silkwood shower after that experience), but at least the TSA agent was pleasant about it.

They have a Bojangles, so that's why I'm giving them the fourth star (and I like the lobby area with the rocking chairs.

This place is a zoo. Tons of travelers. Overall, not a bad airport, but not amazing either. 

The good:

Clear signs. Easy to figure out how to get to diffferent terminals.

The not bad:

The food options

The tiring:

1. Having to go from terminal A or B to terminal E is a bit of a hike. 
2. The A & B terminals are too narrow, so you feel a bit crammed at times.

Overall it isn't a bad airport, but certainly not my favorite to transit.
A lot of dining options and stores, free charging stations at this big clean airport with conventional and recyclable trashes, etc.

This was a pleasant airport to fly into and out of.  The wide open spaces and windows, with trees and rocking chairs inside, made it feel like more than an airport.  There were shops and food options to keep me interested and fed while waiting for my flight.  The TSA was actually quite efficient - thank you for having a proper TSA Pre-Check line!

Takes 30 minutes for the bags to come out to retrieve luggage, then you have to wait another 30+ to get a shuttle to terminal 4. Inside they have a lot of food choices which is nice there's a variety. TSA seems to be always backed up I think they need to add more lanes because they seem to not have enough coverage for us travelers.

The only airport I've left from where I'm comfortable getting there a little less than an hour before flights. Get dropped off, stroll to security (if you've checked in online), wait a maximum of 10 minutes through security, stroll to boarding area. I stroll a lot in the airport. If you need to park your car, give yourself an extra 15 minutes to park and find your way to the terminal. $4 long term parking, $6 daily.. that's freaking amazing. I think I paid $12\/day near LAX once (and that was a cheap place!) and had to walk through an alley to get to a shuttle that smelled like piss. 

Clean facilities, easy to navigate, conveniently located to the city, US airway hub, and Delta too (I think), so many many flights, and lots of little shops to browse while waiting for your flight because you arrived too early. Food options aren't great, but I haven't had to linger in the airport long enough to want to eat here. 

Overall, a convenient airport.

Got to be one of the worst airport in the US. We traveled back from carribeans arrived early only to be told we could not be taxied in. We waited past the arrival time and finally reached the gate to be told the immigration is not ready for us. We waited over 1 hr on the plane. This is an instance one should think how the farm animals are treated, just a number no big deal forget customer service or even compassion. We then waited in long long lines at the security systems that scanned our passports and then to the immigration desk. Then re-checkin luggage and went through security line again. Now we know why they needed 3 hr layover time. So we boarded the next plane to DCA only to be told there was an issue with engine sucking oil at a greater speed than expected so we had to deplane and wait for another plane for 2 more hours. Total travel of what could be 5 turned into almost 12 hrs. Note to self to avoid this airport at all costs.
Nice airport, lots of shopping, spa, food if you have a long layover.

This place gets bigger every time I visit NC. I like it.

+ Free WiFi. So I can work (I mean Yelp) while waiting for my flight. 
+ There are bathroom attendants in the lady's room armed with Listerine, feminine products and mints. All I need is a pair of CFMs and some ambient music and I feel like I'm in the city again. 
+ Food selection is not bad if you have to wait.
+ I love the little chocolate shops.

Clean, nice looking and lots of different places to eat. I've had 2 short lay overs here and each time I have had to walk through the airport to get to a connecting flight so I was able to see a good portion of it. The large windows really brighten up the terminals which makes me think more places (Phoenix Sky Harbor mainly) should follow suit.

I'm leaving on a jet plane"... I'm very fortunate to be only a short distance from the Charlotte Airport. I can get to and from most places in in only one plane ride. 

I usually get here really easily because I hate feeling rushed and standing in the security line. 

Good food options. I like Bad Daddies. 

They are doing some construction and renovations and making this place bigger and better (including the parking).

As a frequent business and leisure traveler, I see more than the usual share of domestic airports in the US of A. While I have had both flights terminating at CLT as well as connecting through CLT, it's more often the later for me, on numerous USAirways and AA flights.

I think that CLT has a unique "large airport with a down home vibe" going for it. Even when I arrive at E gates and have less than an hour to connect to a flight at A or B gates, I don't shudder with terror as I would if having to cross 3-4 concourses, like I would in an airport such as ATL. With CLT, there is a central "hub" that serves as the connecting point for A-E gates. For me, getting from the very end of E to the very end of B took only 15 minutes, and I even had time to stop at Hissin Sushi in the other "hub" between A and B gates. Great success!

You'll love the plethora of white rocking chairs, clean, bright layout of the walkways, and the plentiful stores and restaurants. Restrooms are easy to find, well-stocked, and constantly kept clean by in-restroom staff that offer you paper towels, mouthwash, and mints, call you honey and darling, and work for tips.

Normally, I dread having to connect through any airport, but with CLT's large-yet-compact layout, good (and healthy and indulgent) food choices, plus Southern charm, I won't be as remiss about my next layover there.

NB: I always use the GateGuru App on my phone as we land and are taxiing into get a good idea of airport floorplan, food choices at arrival\/departure gates, etc.

I am not usually a person to write bad reviews about any business. But I will be flying into this airport in the next few weeks so I called to confirm a few things. First, the man answered the phone as if I was putting him out by asking him questions about their airport I have never been to. As I am asking my question he is talking to someone who is standing next to him, and ignoring my question. I then had to repeat myself again, asking about their location of the Pet Relief stations. He said "ummm. I don't think we have any" I asked him if he was sure because I need to know what I am going to do this my dog having several flights with not being able to use the restroom. He then proceeded to tell me that the airport has NO PET RELIEF STATIONS!!!!! You have got to be kidding me. So I am flying into your airport with no place for my dog to use the restroom. This has to be a joke. How in the world can a airport not have a pet relief station! This is absolutely mind blowing to me. So much for making it easy for pet owner to take care of their pets while traveling. They really need to make sure their customer service staff is knowledgeable of their places of work, and have a better attitude while giving stressed out travelers information!

Had a very pleasant layover here.  En route from CDG to SFO it was so nice to be able to sit in a rocking chair and watch the people go by!  The employees at security and check-in were friendly and genuine.   They also have the standards that most airports are supposed to have (Starbucks...hear that, SFO and PHL?) as well as a few expensive special specialty stores i.e. Brookstone that are nice to browse.   They also have a few relatively not-bad-for-you options like Wolfgang Puck Express and a few sandwich and salad and smoothie stops, and they are kind of spread out but the airport isn't huge so it's an easy walk between them.

Not a bad airport. There's relatively cheap parking and security lines seem to move fairly quickly, especially during the Monday morning rush when they have all the scanners going. Could up the ante a bit with the quality of restaurant choices but there are enough Starbucks spread throughout to cure that coffee jones quickly.  Also, they have free wi-fi.  What a novel, and welcome, concept!

But... DO NOT check your bag flying into Charlotte Douglas. Unless things have changed from the last time I did it, you're looking at 45 minutes of standing around.

I evaluate airports according to entertainment value, ease of mobility, cleanliness and staff attitude. Lets face it, you could be stuck anytime with our struggling airline systems, mechanical problems or weather conditions. 

Charlotte DIA is easy to get in and out of. Rental car pickup is very reasonable and fast. 4 stars. 

Parking cost is low compared to my city. 4 stars 

Security, police and TSA personnel in this airport are awesome. Very nice people (Oakland, CA Airport needs to train with them). 4 stars

The security lines are congested and slow.  2 stars. 

Bathrooms are very clean with attendants. 5 stars. 

Shops are just enough to keep you entertained.  3 stars. 

Food service is good, there are a reasonable number of choices and they have a Carolina BBQ stop that is very good by airport standards. They offer fast food to casual dining. This rates 4 stars. 

Flight delays are not to bad but they could use improvement. I give them 3 stars. 

If you check luggage the wait averages 20 minutes. Not bad. 5 stars

They provide rocking chairs and a massage spa. They also have a Grand Piano in the main atrium and some really talented people stop to play for you. 5 stars 

The SHOE SHINE!!! Best in America. My opinion. Amazing deal for 5 bucks plus tip. I bring extra shoes just to show up for this. Sorry to you guys in St. Louis that have held the title so long. "6******" stars.

Free WIFI. 5 stars

Overall a great airport to keep you entertained if on time or stranded. Nice friendly employees in all areas of the airport.  4 stars****

Rocking chairs in the airport?? !  An entire row of them!   What an interesting and distinguishing feature.   Also, each area is lined with various eateries, including CPK and Burger King.  Unfortunately, I dined on the latter instead of the former, because I didn't see it in time and was rushing to connect to a flight.

Been through CDIA multiple times for layovers, and have always enjoyed my time. Very clean and always seems to give the illusion of being brand new. They offer plenty of food and shopping which is nice, but as usual they gouge your wallet while doing so. Not going to lie though, sometimes finding your gate can be a struggle. As they can have you walking for hours lost, and sometimes trying to navigate through some large crowds due to this airport being a major hub for the east coast domestic scene (Despite the international tag).

 Is it the worst airport, not in the least, but it has room for improvement. As mentioned above it has some good amenities to keep you busy during a layover, but I would not want to be stuck here for an extended amount of time honestly.

We are very fortunate in Charlotte to have such a nice airport. Even when I'm anxiety-ridden and sweaty getting myself to the airport and through security, the large atrium with its trees and white rocking chairs always calms me down. 

There have been many improvements to Charlotte Douglas in recent years, including a few restaurants and bars that feel pleasant and inviting instead of like you're settling for a quick, overpriced meal. Market 1897 is a delightful stop to pause and explore, whether or not you choose to dine there. 

I'm excited to see the coming additions to our airport, and I'm looking forward to seeing our Queen Charlotte statue back where she belongs once construction is complete. 

I went with 5 stars for Charlotte Douglas because as far as airports go, it ranks very high for me in terms of comfort and accessibility. Airports are inherently stressful and busy, but CLT pulls it off with grace.

We're usually routed through here for our Caribbean trips as well. It's a pretty decent airport, not as much hustle and bustle like LAX or Philadelphia has. I think because of us coming through this airport so much, I'd like to explore Charlotte a little more, it seems like a pretty cool place :)

I LOVE this airport! I had to go through a flight transfer flying from Orlando, we made a pit stop here, and then continued to my destination Chicago. I had about an hour to kill here so I browsed the shops. Not too expensive actually. I happened to stop by a cute little jewlery\/accessory store with really nice things!! I was tempted to buy stuff from here but I was on a tight budget so decided not to. Although I was only browsing, the store employee was very nice and friendly. The architecture of the inside of this airport is very nice, big, HUGE ceilings and very open spaces. You don't feel overwhelmed walking through here. Not crowded at all. Everyone seems to be calm and collected which adds a nice vibe to the atmosphere. Like I said, I LOVE this airport! Everything about it. I hope to fly through here again soon. Hope Hope Hope!!!

Living in Jackson, MS, I can rarely find direct flights anywhere. This means lots of layover time spent at lots of airports around the Southeast. Most of my air-travel time takes me through the Charlotte Douglas International Airport.

I've spent so much time at this airport the past few years, I've joked that I should buy an apartment in Charlotte just in case!

This is a mid-sized airport, which is nice. It's not so big that you could easily get lost or confused, but it's not so small that you'll be terribly bored. There's an okay variety of food options. Mostly fast food and standard airport fare. There's a huge food court located centrally where you can hang out while you eat. 

There's lots of seating to be found. There are even rocking chairs! Which I love. The airport's got free wi-fi so you won't get too bored while you wait for your flight. I've never had any issues with rude staff or security here. Overall, my experiences with the Charlotte Airport have been pleasant!

This is a decent airport. I will warn you, make sure you take a picture of where you park because the parking lot is huge. I always arrive at least an hour ahead before my flight in case TSA takes forever. They do have a few shops and restaurants in the airport. I haven't had any issues. So far, it's an ok airport!

These reviews are censored.  I wouldn't believe any of them.  All my updates are deleted that mention the EU and British travel warning for North Carolina due to its anti LGBT laws.  I'm writing this sitting in the Admirals club at this airport.  This fact is significant and is related to the primary customer experience of all LGBT people like me who find themselves having to travel through here since the state government has created a hostile environment for LGBT people here.  It's really incredible that I'm being censored over and over again.   Apparently my writings about my personal experience traveling through this airport for the past 20 years here is not valid and needs to be censored and silenced.  Apparently that's what you can expect to happen to you here if you run into any problems here.  You will simply be ignored since that is their state law now.  I would choose another airport that doesn't rely on censorship to get its ratings up.

This airport was not bad at all.  The layout is a little annoying but the tsa was actuality pretty fast here.  The car rental center was a little confusing to get to. The service here was fast and friendly.  It's US airways main hub, so they end up with a lot of over booked flights. And giving up your seat is definitely worth it.

This airport is nice, especially if you're in the American Airlines terminal.  Lots of shopping and restaurants, and free Wi-Fi.  The only complaint I have is if you are flying in a small plane from somewhere nearby to make a connection for a longer flight, they're usually in gates that are very far apart, and I've missed my connection multiple times because they don't give priority to the small planes (so even if I've landed on time, we can't pull into a gate to get off, and by the time they do, the connection is too tight to make...even when running across the airport).  If you're stuck there for a while, I suggest going to a sit down restaurant and ordering some food and drinks near an outlet, and working off the free internet :)

I have no idea how things are on the Departure side of Security.   But, for anyone picking up a passenger here, this is one of the worst airports I can imagine.  Other than a Starbucks (w\/o seating) and a magazine shop, and a "Cafe", there is nothing.

I really like this airport.. Free wifi everywhere and cool little rocking chairs to sit in while u surf and people watch. It's well laid out (easy to get to all your gates) and a central, easy toe reach, area offering BBQ among other standard eats.  It is clean and well-maintained too.
Clean, some renovations under way.

One of the nicest airports in the United States! Plenty of shopping, as well as food options within the airport's gates. One of the few airports that resembles a shopping mall more than an actual airport!
A lot of places to eat in the US Airways terminal. I only had 1 stop here but they have white chairs everywhere which is pretty cool and free wifi.

Nice airport but I'm deducting a star because the free wifi didn't work. Cleaner than most New York airports, and all the terminals are connected so you never have a Denver type situation where you're panicking waiting for the tram. The walkway in the terminals is very wide, so it doesn't seem to get too badly obstructed,  and there's a number of food options. It's a pretty standard airport, decent for connections.

This airport has the rudest employees-absolutely disappointed by the outcome here.The bathrooms had a lot of tagging on the doors and not to mention there was no toilet paper.
Delta is never receiving my services, the front desk guy Ayman was unhelpful and didn't let me finish my question repeating what he had to say and I than got fired up and told him, "listen I have not finished my question, rather than assuming and repeating yourself over 4x please stop and listen."
Ayman from DELTA has no customer service at all.
I mean I understand that you have to deal with a cancelled flight, but don't hate on me if you have a shitty job-move on punk! Anyways, bad experience.
"Bye FeliCa!

I started a new job last September and I travel by air 2-3 times a month.  Most of my travel is to Charlotte, so I have either flown in or out of this airport around 40 times recently. In general, my experiences have been very good.

Since I don't live here, I can't comment on parking. I work in the Uptown area, so I just take a taxi and walk once I am in my hotel, so can't comment on rental cars. However, I will say that the taxi cab line can be quite  long, especially if you come in on a Sunday. I've used Uber several times and it's very convenient.  They pick you up by door E.

There are a few decent restaurants in the atrium: sushi, seafood, wine bar and mexican. I've eaten at all but I like the wine bar and the chicken pesto flatbread. Not cheap, but it's an airport, what do you expect?

Others have commented on the rocking chairs (quaint), bathroom attendants (annoying\/intrusive, to me, but others like it), and the long walks (nothing compared to Philly intn'l terminal. I needed a snack). Overall,  nice, clean airport with good amenities.

This airport is practically a mall. It has the typical airport shops such as  sandwich shops, coffee shops, souvenir shops, etc. in addition to Pandora, a sushi bar, the body shop... too many to name. It was actually quite pleasantly overwhelming and I was kind of wishing I'd had longer layover just so that I could explore more.

With this having been my 3rd airport stop of the day, I was elated at the atmosphere here; upscale, clean & just so many options to keep you occupied while you wait.

The bathrooms are the greatest airport bathrooms ever. In some of them (I think the ones closer to the shopping area) have an attendant and a few toiletries available. One was so spacious it had a semi-private vanity area where I was able too lay all my crap out to do my hair and make-up.

One more reason why Charlotte is awesome. Love it!

I seem to go through this airport a lot -- probably because it's a hub for American Airlines. The downside to this airport is that it is so big that it can take a long time to get from one terminal to the next, which is problematic if you have a short time to make a quick connection. I have also always found it to be very busy and so you are best building in some extra time. The positives are that because it is so big, there are plenary of restaurants, bars, cafes and kiosks where you can enjoy a number of different foods and drinks. So if you are stuck in this airport it's not the end of the world.

Nice clean airport.  Lots and lots of flights so it gets crowded.  Once everyone is gone, it's nice.  Bathrooms are spectacular. For those of you trying to connect to the wifi at the end of terminal A, go to gate A6 and view at the airport map nearby.  Then connect.  There is spotty connections at the end of that terminal hampering the user agreement website from openong.

This place is huge, I feel like I'm at some kind of mall or something. It's by far the nicest and newest looking airport I've been to. Didn't mind being stuck in this nice airport for an hour or so. Got a little treat at Pinkberry and walked around. There are plenty of shops and restaurants and I never had a problem with finding anything or getting to or on my plane. Oh, and very clean!

What's not like about the Charlotte airport?  It's clean, it's friendly, there are bathroom attendants, there are rocking chairs, there's BBQ and a wine bar, there's a guy playing Rihanna on a baby grand.  Of course there is currently an idiot sitting in the middle of the walkway eating frozen yogurt but everyone is too polite here to call them out on it.

Possibly as bad or worse than Atlanta with the crowds!

I've heard this is the 6th busiest airport in the world? It's about 500th in a pleasant experience.

First and hopefully last time connecting through here.

This airport is just about always busy - and that can be a little annoying. Wanna walk from point A to point B? Well, don't be in a hurry, because there are 5 million (slight exaggeration) people in your way.

BUT, they have decent restaurant options, and plenty of them. On top of that, the people in the international area are about as nice as they can be: One of them actually called me "sweetie". I almost broke down crying because it was so nice to be treated so well after spending several months out of the country. I am telling you... the customer service in the United States is beyond. And the CLT is top notch!

Additionally, the airport is pretty small, all things considered. I was at the very end of terminal B when I arrived. Had to head to D, which was the opposite side of the airport. I think that with all the foot traffic, it took me a whopping 10-15 min. Not too shabby... but I will admit that I am a master maneuverer, and walk with relaxed-looking lightning speed. So maybe add a little extra time for the lollygaggers. Nice thing is there're some little shops there in the middle. Relax, check it out. Then be on your merry way.

OH! One last pointer: AWESOME place to come in internationally... it took me like 3 seconds (again, slight exaggeration) to get through customs. There were plenty of lines, re-entering through security was also well-organized. It honestly is THE best place (and I've been through a lot of airports internationally) I have ever been when re-entering the US of A. Highly suggest making this your international airport (when possible).

This is my home airport and everytime I do have to fly somewhere, I can always expect to look forward to a quick check-in. I kinda cut it close last weekend though. I had a 7:55am flight to Kansas City and didn't get off to work until 6:30am, traveling from South Carolina, south of the Ballantyne area. I made it to the airport at 7:05am, parked in Long Term Parking (which has always been pleasant, except for the few times that I had to go find my car....but that's completely on me, haha), missed a shuttle bus, but another one pulled in not even two minutes later...got to the terminal, printed my pass in the self check in kiosk, and got in the line to get through security. It appeared to be kinda long, but I got through in less than 5 minutes. I was sitting in front of my gate for Kansas City at 7:25am. Now if that aint quick, I don't know what is. The beauty of Charlotte-Douglas Airport is it's US Airways main hub, so you can get several nonstop flights to the big cities in the country (LA, Miami, Chicago, Las Vegas, NYC, San Francisco, Seattle, Atlanta, and the list goes on). I also just found out that Charlotte has nonstop service to Paris and will begin nonstop service to Honolulu and Rio de Janeiro (all on US Airways). The free Wi-Fi is always sweet if you need something to do to kill some time. There are plenty of places to eat from your standard fast food chains to some nice bars and restaurants.

As a New York City native, I couldn't stand the hassles of JFK, LaGuardia and Newark. I can get to wherever I need to in the country from Charlotte and it has never been a hassle.

Given that this is presently my "home airport" I'd better know it enough to review it given that I feel quick to comment on the other airports I've been through.

Bottom line: the place is relatively clean, easy to navigate (in comparison) and is almost done up-fitting the retail to come up to the current trend of "mall-like" experiences.  

All terminals are span out from a center like the hub and spoke system of the airlines.  The center court in the middle is best known for its cluster of shoppes, restaurants and (best loved) row of white rocking chairs that ironically back up to the people-mover walkways.  People watching, alone, is worth the price of admission and the vast open space feels busy and energetic during prime time, but never stuffy.

E Terminal is they newest and definitely feels so. If you fly international from Charlotte, you will be there.  Seems there is a bigger selection of stores here but all terminals have some options.

For those parking at Charlotte, you've got the usual choices of hourly, daily, long-tern and remote- each with successive price decreases but increasing distances from the terminal.  A flurry of busses constantly circuits from the lots to the terminal and, unless you arrive late at night, are plentiful and well-marked.  After hours we have much better success contacting an airport employee to let them know which bus we fare looking for.  Just remember where you park- long term one is very different from long term 2!

For those wanting a higher level of service, there is also terminal level valet and business valet.  While I get the convenience of pulling up to the terminal and dropping off they keys, I do not understand the business valet- it is further away than remote parking and you still have to ride a bus.  Yes, they will change your oil and clean the car (for an additional price) but the premium you pay here does not justify the product.  My advice: skip business valet entirely.

Otherwise, CLT is a typical airport but modern, clean, and open enough to make your time there easier to enjoy.
Charlotte is my favorite airport!  They are doing major changes in order to improve the overall experience and help improve the Queen City.
Easy to navigate and lots of shops.  LaCoste inside an airport???

Being a frequent traveler I am lucky to call this my home airport.  Plenty of dining \/ shopping options, easy to get around, direct flights to most places I travel...not too large to navigate.

What holds back a five star rating from me is the time it takes to retrieve checked bags, and the seemingly long time it takes to get a bus to long term parking.

Overall, one of the best airports I've been through.

They need to fix this airport or just put it out to pasture.  No bathroom divides for the stand up stalls, bathroom attendants that like to watch you pee or they enjoy the casual  talk while you take a crap.  You board the planes like you did back in the 50s outside in the rain and snow.  My flights average  93% late on arrivals and departures, I should know as I track it.  You do get your exercise and play the game called "Musical Gates".  Just my 0.00000002 worth.
Clean and friendly.  Have no complaints except that you tend to always sit on the runway awhile.

I've been to so many airports over the years that I can't even name them all. In the morning, this airport is certainly quiet. But it's also dead. I came in on a red eye. By 6, almost nothing in the D terminal is open. And the one sit down restaurant that is open has no outlets. While it's nice to have charging stations by the gates, travelers who work like to sit down and enjoy their meal while banging out some work and charging their equip. More restaurants with outlets and open before 7 for early travelers would go a long way to improving this place.
They have bathroom attendants now. It threw me off guard when I walked in. She had your typical mouthwash, tampons and tip jar. Nothing fancy. Kinda unnecessary

Ideally I'd give this airport 3.5 stars, but since that's not possible, I'll round up....

My family and I have been here multiple times in the past two years, as this airport is a hub for US Air. We've been here when it's been quiet and also when it's been teeming with people. When quiet, it's lovely: there is an airy, open central food court that has a lot of light and open space. There are some neat art pieces and mobiles\/suspended kinetic sculptures which are cool, and rocking chairs in which to relax. The airport's signage is clear and everything is really well-marked.
